awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Metal-implanted materials (MIMs) for fast, cost-effective and reproducible mixing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project includes improving the reproducibility of automated life science workflows while simultaneously reducing their carbon footprint. Automated life science workflows are increasingly prevalent in medical (e.g., laboratory tests and diagnostics) and research (e.g., next generation sequencing) applications, and mixing is a ubiquitous and often repeatedly performed operation in these assays. The novel mixing technology to be developed will confer myriad benefits. By reducing assay turnaround times and improving assay reliability, it will decrease wait times for medical screening, diagnosis and monitoring, enabling faster diagnoses and treatments. By decreasing the materials costs of the assays, this technology may reduce the costs of medical testing and improve access to care. It also can enhance partnerships between academic and industry laboratories by giving academic laboratories access to industry workflows that are currently prohibitively expensive. Finally, by eliminating a substantial portion of the single-use plastic consumed by assays, this novel mixing technology will help curb the waste generated by life science assays, which will help alleviate the single-use plastic waste crisis. 
 
The proposed project will deliver an innovative mixing technology that is based on a photo-acoustic streaming phenomenon. Briefly, when glass implanted with metal nanoparticles (metal-implanted materials (MIMs)) is excited by a pulsed laser, it causes an adjacent fluid (liquid or gas) to begin streaming for the duration of the illumination. This streaming creates an opportunity to precisely control mixing, but key technical challenges include optimizing the MIMs’ form factor and devising an effective, yet also inexpensive, illumination system. The proposed project’s objectives address these challenges by: (i) evaluating the effectiveness of mixing solutions with a novel MIM form factor that can be incorporated easily into existing automated life science workflows, (ii) determining if functional MIMs can be fabricated in bulk by procuring them from a supplier and characterizing them for nanoparticle implantation and laser-induced solution streaming, and (iii) testing an alternative laser light source that powers mixing and consists of a low-cost light emitting diode (LED) laser.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
1. Background

Transfection, or intracellular delivery of effector molecules into cells, is a cornerstone of gene and cell therapies. Viral vectors show high transfection efficiency, but are costly, labor-intensive, have limited packaging capabilities and are associated with high risks of immunogenicity and oncogenesis. Chemical vectors (i.e. lipid or polymer-based) are safer alternatives, but show low transfection efficiency in primary cells, limited endosomal escape, and delayed cargo unpacking. Membrane permeabilization show promise for overcoming these challenges, but these methods (i.e. electroporation, nucleofection, cell squeezing) still suffer from tradeoffs between cell viability and transfection efficiency.

Vapor nanobubble (VNB)-based photoporation has recently emerged as an attractive alternative for membrane permeabilization. This technique uses plasmonic gold nanoparticles and pulsed lasers to create pores in the cell membrane through which macromolecules can diffuse. Although VNB-based photoporation has shown efficient delivery of a range of cargoes even in difficult-to-transfect cell types, mixed reports regarding the cytotoxicity of AuNPs limits the application of photoporation when developing therapies where modified cells will be reintroduced into the body.

Quantum Med aims to overcome the challenges of photoporation by directly patterning nano-scale gold implanted areas on biocompatible materials (i.e. glass or quartz) to create photoporation substrates that are safe, self-contained, and controllable. This technique is based on the photo-acoustic streaming phenomenon recently discovered by the Quantum Med founding team, where metal implanted glass substrates create cavitation bubbles when excited by a pulsed laser.

 

2. Major Award Activities

2.1 Business Development

Voice of the Customer: 30+ customer interviews were performed through NSF’s Beat the Odds Bootcamp (BTOB) to explore needs in different application areas. For transfection, over 75% of customers interviewed validated challenges related to current methods, including cell viability, efficiency of transfection, optimization time, safety risks, and high costs.

Business Model Validation: BTOB helped us conduct a thorough market size analysis and competitive landscape evaluation. Through customer discovery interviews, we identified the key performance criteria where our technology needs to surpass existing gold-standard transfection methods. Additionally, we confirmed that the intracellular delivery market presents a promising opportunity, with significant growth potential and a total addressable market exceeding $2 billion.

2.2 Research Objectives

The following specific objectives aimed to de-risk the technical and scientific aspects of this opportunity:

2.2.1 Evaluate a low-cost laser system: High power pulsed laser systems needed to generate photo-acoustic streaming tend to be high-cost and pose challenges related to low accessibility and safety risks. We identified and validated a low-cost pulsed laser system that replicates the capabilities of high-power, expensive systems to create vapor bubbles in combination with gold implanted substrates.

2.2.2 Nano-patterning of substrates: The resolution of photomasks used in photolithography is typically in the 1-10 micrometer range. Thus, typical chromium masks could not be used to achieve the desired nanometer-scale patterning. To overcome this challenge, we invented and tested a novel method for using track-etched polyimide membranes as photomasks to pattern nano-scale implanted areas.

2.2.3 Determining biological feasibility: We finally aimed to determine the biological feasibility and demonstrate proof of concept (POC) for intracellular delivery. First, we assessed the viability of cells in contact with the substrate to ensure biocompatibility of the material. Second, we conducted tests to confirm cell membrane disruption when exposed to the substrate combined with light.

3. Award Impact

3.1 IP generation: We invented several new techniques during this award, including nano-patterning of implanted substrates and substrate-based photoporation of cells. These were submitted as invention disclosures to the University of Houston (UH) Office of Technology Transfer and Innovation and a U.S. Provisional Patent Application (Application No 63/606,349) was filed  on 12/05/2023 by UH and QuantumMed.

3.2 Academic dissemination and professional development: Two manuscripts, currently under preparation, resulted from the research carried out during this award. Manuscripts related to the biological application of implantation substrate-based photoporation will be submitted to biomedical journals, while those related to the patterning of substrates will be submitted to chemistry journals. In addition, this award has provided training and professional development for one postdoc and two graduate students at the University of Houston.

3.3 Broader Impacts The work supported by this award has contributed to the following fields: in quantum mechanics, the use of plasmonic nanoparticles to generate VNBs introduces a new application of photothermal effects. In optical systems, the project advances the use of pulsed lasers for precise control in cell membrane permeabilization, enhancing the field of laser-based technologies. In molecular biology, the new transfection method improves the efficiency and safety of intracellular delivery, offering a powerful tool for gene and cell therapies.

 Broader societal impacts include developing a safer, scalable, and efficient transfection technique, with the potential to unlock new treatments for genetic disorders, cancer, and other diseases. Furthermore, reducing the cost and complexity of therapeutic development will contribute to a more equitable distribution of cutting-edge innovations across geographies and healthcare systems.


Last Modified: 11/27/2024
Modified by: Elisabet Rosas
